div1.p: Benjamin offers a collection of letters concerning Madame Curie, and a letter of Abraham Lincoln that is for sale.

div1.head: Letter from Mary A. Benjamin to Philip Showalter Hench, October 27, 1939
div1.opener:
WALTER R. BENJAMIN
655 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N. Y.
__________________________________________________
AUTOGRAPH LETTERS AND HISTORICAL DOCUMENTS
MARY A. BENJAMIN, Editor
_______________
Oct. 27, 1939.
Dr. P.S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I have recently obtained two fine
autographs items, which I think may be of considerable
interest to you, so I write to give details about
them.

The first is a collection of over one hundred
letters of famous scientists, chemists, writers,
etc., written entirely on the subject of radium,
and about Mme Curie. All of the letters mention
her or radium. Some are splendid discussions of
the subject. Most were written at the time of Mmee
Curie's visit to this country, when she was pre-
sented with a gram of radium, at a cost of $100,000.
They give details of her trip through the country,
of receptions, etc., tendered her. All of the
writers of the letters are important personnages,
but of chief interest are three letters, two type-
written ones, excellent in contents, and signed by
Mme Curie herself, and one letter from Mrs. Meloney,
her sponsor, sending a two line ANS of Mme Curie to
Dr. Kunst, which is enclosed.

I hardly need tell you of the rarity of
anything on this subject or on Mme Curie. In our
experience we have had only one letter of hers. I
have had a standing order with all the European
dealers for anything of hers that might turn up,
but she is hopeless. They tell me she is as rare
over there as here.

I believe it would be well worth your while
to look the collection over. I would gladly send

it on approval. My price on the collection is $125.00.

The other item is a medical item par excellence,
although a Lincoln item. It is of such unusual interest
that I feel you should at least know of it. I enclose
a transcript of the letter, which I will ask you to
return, if you do not care to keep the letter, which
is priced at $75. It shows Lincoln interested in
medical details, which you would hardly have expected
he would have time to look into. I imagine also
that disinfectants were fairly new in those days,
were they not?

Let me know if you wish to see either of these
collectionsitems or both on approval.
